allData.name: BIOGEN - Genetic Biobank

bb_core.Description: BIOGEN is the Biobank of of Genetic Samples of the Department of Medical Genetic and Rare Orthopaedic Diseases of Istituto Ortopedico Rizzoli, directed by Dr. Luca Sangiorgi. BIOGEN has been created in order to collect high quality biological materials of patients affected by skeletal dysplasias and other rare diseases. The samples collected, more than 6500 different biospecimens, cover many fields of genetic and genomic research applications; in fact, our biobank includes human blood, blood components and derivates, DNA, RNA, urine, serum, tissues. Most of the samples are collected for diagnostic purpose, but patients are asked to use the blood/buccal scraping for research scopes, after reading and signing informed consent agreement. Other samples are collected only for research finality, like tissues, urine and serum

allData.name: Bank "Cells, tissues and DNA from patients with neuromuscular diseases", Ist. Neurologico C. Besta

bb_core.Description: The biobank, created since 1986 for tissue and since 1991 for cells, as part of the routine diagnostic activity of the Division, is concerned with muscle tissue, DNA and muscle cells from patients with neuromuscular diseases. At present the biobank stores more than 7000 muscle tissue samples, about 4000 DNA samples and 1200 myoblast cell lines. The stored material, from more than 7000 patients, is mainly characterized at the histological, biochemical and clinical level. On the basis of new scientific discoveries and whenever new genes responsible for muscle diseases are discovered, muscle biopsies, patient clinical data and patient DNA, are continuously reassessed in order to find the precise molecular diagnosis.
bb_core.Additional_Associated_data_available: Minimal clinical data, additional can be obtained upon request

allData.name: Biobank of skeletal muscle, peripheral nerve, DNA and cell cultures

bb_core.Description:
The "Biobank of skeletal muscle, peripheral nerve, DNA and cell cultures"  is part of the Unit for Neuromuscular and Rare Diseases. Since 1999 it has been partially funded by Telethon Foundation and has become a member of Telethon Network of Genetic Biobanks.
Since 2002 it has become a partner of the Eurobiobank Project, funded by the European Community, initially coordinated by Eurordis (European Organization for Rare Diseases) and currently by Telethon.
From 200 2 until July 2005 the Biobank was ISO 9001 Quality certified through Det Norske Veritas.
Since July 2005 the Biobank quality Certification is provided by BVQI Society. 
Since July 2013 it has been part of the European research infrastructure Biobanking and Biomolecular Resources Research Infrastructure (BBMRI).

The Biobank stores a remarkable number of biological samples from patients affected with different rare neuromuscular disorders and the samples are analyzed for both diagnostic and research purposes.
Indeed, once the patients have given their written consent, the Biobank stores bioptic specimens that are sent every week  to the laboratory for diagnostic purposes.
In detail, the Biobank yearly receives about 250 specimens from different Italian Hospitals and from the Hospital of Lugano, Switzerland. Also, over 100 biological samples are distributed every year to prestigious Italian and foreign research Institutes
The Biobank presently stores over 10,500 skeletal muscle biopsies and 450 peripheral nerve samples for morphological studies and around 4400 embedded samples for electron microscopy observation. Also, several samples of DNA (extracted from muscle tissue and/or DNA) and cell cultures (fibroblasts and myoblasts).
Biological samples include the following disorders: muscular dystrophies, congenital myopathies, metabolic myopathies, mitochondrial encephalomyopathies, inflammatory myopathies, spinal muscular atrophies, motorneuron disorders, canalopathies, genetic and acquired peripheral  neuropathies, systemic disorders with neuromuscular involvement.
The Biobank can count on a centralized database and on a website to facilitate presentation of and access to sample collections in order to guarantee the highest degree of security, privacy and reliability.
bb_core.Additional_networks_inventories: Telethon Network of Genetic Biobanks, Eurobiobank
bb_core.Additional_Biomaterial_prepared: samples embedded in Spurr's resin for ultrastructural examination

allData.name: Biobank of the Institute of Rare Diseases Research/Institute of Health Carlos III (IIER-ISCIII)

bb_core.Description:
The National Rare Disease Biobank collects and stores biological samples of people affected by rare diseases, relatives and controls. Its mission is to support national and international research. These samples are available for research, both etiologic and preventive aspects, as oriented to the search for new treatments and prognostic factors.

The National Rare Disease Biobank offers the following services:

  • Processing of biological samples
  • Storage of samples and data associated with the National Registry of Rare   Diseases
  • Storage of samples and data associated with the Registry of Autism Spectrum Disorders
  • Provision of samples for research projects by investigators
  • Access to sample collections of the European network Eurobiobank
  • Access to sample collections of other European biobanks
bb_core.Type_of_host_institution: Instittute of Rare Diseases Research, IIER, ISCIII

We are convinced that publicizing sample collections through membership to specialized international catalogues is the best manner to achieve this goal.

allData.name: CIBERER Biobank

bb_core.Description:
The CIBERER Biobank (CBK) is a public, non-profit-making biobank that was set up in 2008 by the Biomedical Network Research Centre for Rare Diseases (CIBERER) and is located in Valencia at the Centro Superior de Investigación en Salud Pública (CSISP).

The CBK forms part of the structure of CIBER, a public Consortium set up at the initiative of the Carlos III Health Institute (Ministry of Economy, Industry and Competitiveness), and belonging to the Rare Diseases Area, created to act as a reference, coordinate and foster excellence research on rare diseases in Spain.

CBK was founded with the aim of serving diagnostic and therapeutic research, facilitating the availability of high-quality biological material to carry this out. Additionally, it was set up to contribute to solve one of the main problems encountered in research on these pathologies: the dispersion of samples due to the low prevalence of rare diseases. This point is of special relevance at a time when the proliferation of different biobanks could hinder the concentration of cases required to carry out research into rare diseases.

CIBERER Biobank adheres to principles for responsible custodianship, which require planning and transparent policies to ensure long-term physical integrity of samples as well as maintaining their privacy and confidentiality.

Biospecimen distribution to researchers is based on principles of scientific merit and access in a timely and equitable manner. Any researcher who wishes to request the CBK for a biological sample should fill in a sample request application form, enclosing a report on the research project for which this is required, as well as any relevant data on the evaluation of its viability (human and financial resources, infrastructure, etc.). The Ethics Committee and the Scientific Committee will proceed to evaluate the appropriateness of donating the biological sample requested and issue a report. If the decision is favorable, the sample will be sent to the applicant, after the researcher in charge has undertaken to comply with the conditions established by current legislation in Data Protection Act and Act 14/2007 on Biomedical Research by signing a Material Transfer Agreement (please refer to Appendix 7). The commitment refers to the proper use of samples, given that they constitute scarce research material with high scientific value and to the confidentiality of the associated information or any that may stem from its study.

The biobank was initially set up according to a centralized model, where all samples were processed, stored and given by the biobank's physical premises. Later on, CIBERER's Scientific Board decided to switch to a mixed centralized/decentralized model in order to include other CIBERER sample collections which are not deposited at the biobank. Thus, at present, the biobank works with both types of collections.
bb_core.Percentage_of_rare_diseases_in_your_regi: >80%, the remaining being matched controls (usually not affected relatives)

allData.name: Cell line and DNA Biobank from patients affected by Genetic Diseases

bb_core.Description:
IGG-GB was established in 1975 as part of the "UOSD Centro di diagnostica genetica e biochimica delle malattie metaboliche" Laboratory. Being situated at the G. Gaslini Institute with a longstanding tradition and internationally recognized expertise in the diagnosis of, and research into, rare genetic diseases, the Biobank has constantly benefited from the extensive Institutional facilities.

In 2010, IGG-GB was officially recognised by the Regione Liguria (DGR n. 34-2010).

Supported by Telethon grants since 1993, at present IGG-GB is part of Telethon Network of Genetic Biobanks (http://biobanknetwork.telethon.it/).

IGG-GB operates in compliance within the Italian and international regulations.

The Biobank consists of biospecimens (dermal fibroblasts, EBV-lymphoblasts, amniocytes, chorionic villous cells and RNAs/DNAs) derived from patients affected by more than 250 different genetic defects. To date, the activity of the Biobank is acknowledged in more than 160 scientific publications.
bb_core.Additional_networks_inventories: Telethon Network of Genetic Biobanks, Eurobiobank

allData.name: Galliera Genetic Bank

bb_core.Description: The GGB is located at Genetics Laboratory – of Galliera Hospital in Genoa and  collects samples from patients affected by chromosomal disorders several genetic diseases  since 1983. To date the biobank stores 10.179 biological specimens derived from more than  200 genetic diseases, the majority of them are well characterized and are made available to researchers. The biobank has been supported by Telethon grant since 1993 and in 2008 become a partner of the Telethon Network of Genetic Biobanks (TNGB). The biobank operates in accordance with Italian and International regulations. Since 2008,  its operational system has been ISO 9001 certified and in 2010, the biobank was officially recognised by the Regione Liguria. Since the beginning of its activity the biobank has made available its services to biomedical community by establishing, storing and distributing biospecimens, getting more than 100 acknowledgements in scientific papers.
bb_core.Additional_networks_inventories: The Thelethon Network of Genetic Biobanks

allData.name: Incontinentia Pigmenti Genetic BioBank

bb_core.Description:
Incontinentia Pigmenti Genetic Biobank

The Incontinentia Pigmenti Genetic Biobank (IPGB) is a no-profit service  unit of Institute of Genetics and Biophysics, "Adriano Buzzati Traverso”, IGB-ABT, of CNR, aimed to the collection, processing, preservation, storage and distribution of human biological materials and the data associated, from patients suffering from a rare genetic disease, Incontinentia pigmenti (IP; OMIM#308300), for diagnostic investigation, research and therapeutic use.

bb_contribution.Please_write_a_few_lines_explaining_why_: The Malta BioBank catalogue could contribute to the RD-Connect catalogue through it's various Rare Disease collecitons.

allData.name: Malta BioBank

bb_core.Description:
The Malta BioBank forms part of the new inter-faculty Centre for Molecular Medicine and BioBanking at the University of Malta. It is the Maltese National node (BBMRI.mt) in the BioBanking and BioMolecular resources Research Infrastructure, European Research Infrastructure Consortium (BBMRI-ERIC). The Malta BioBank is a full partner in RD-Connect and an associate partner in EuRenOmics.

The Malta BioBank is a founding partner in EuroBioBank – the European Network of DNA, Cell and Tissue banks for Rare Diseases (http://www.eurobiobank.org/) with a focus on improving operating procedures for the exchange and use of samples and quality control of samples.

The Malta BioBank also forms part of the Electronic Infrastructure for Thalassaemia Research Network (ITHANET).

The Malta BioBank’s management committee includes experts in: Ethics; Law and Sociology who together form the Ethics, Legal and Societal Issues (ELSI) working party of BBMRI.mt.

In addition there is a Quality Management Team, bioinformatics experts, a biobanking education officer and a project support office which deals with financial matters. Other experts include Consultant Medical Geneticists, Neurologists, Genetic researchers, experts in biobanking of blood and tissues.

The Malta BioBank is split in two, the Population Bank and the Clinical Bank.

The Population Bank is a discovery tool for biobanking / population-led research and includes a random collection of Maltese citizens and a cohort of healthy Maltese senior citizens. New funding for the Maltese Genome Project will further develop the Population Bank. The business model for the Population Bank is being developed in the form of a research co-operative whereby the donor of a sample is not only a participant of the study but an owner of the research, thus a partner (MiData project).

The business model of the Clinical Bank is based on a collaboration between the University of Malta, the Department of Health and Mater Dei Hospital’s departments including Pathology, Paediatrics, Neurology and Oncology. The clinical catalogue holds a number of disease collections including: the Globin Bank; Parkinson’s Disease (PD); Diabetes; Multiple Sclerosis; Renal Disorders; various cancers including breast, colon, lung and gastric cancer; and a number of rare diseases

  1. DFDFKMLKLKThe Malta BioBank provides population based biomolecular tools to promote biomedical research both in Malta and in collaboration with other Euro-Mediterranean countries so as to improve healthcare.

core.Description:
The "Neuromuscular Bank of Tissues and DNA samples" (NMTB) at the  Neuromuscular Center of the University of Padova was started in 1978.
Cases of genetic and acquired muscle diseases have been collected from the linked clinical units and from many other Neurological  and Pediatric Centres throughout Italy.

The bank includes tissues and DNA from patients affected with a variety of neuromuscular disorders.

A parallel patients’ clinical follow-up and appropriate molecular analyses enable to assess more precise diagnoses.  

The bank stores 8000 DNA samples, more than 10.000 muscle biopsis and about 200 serum samples from patients and relatives with inherited neuromuscular disorder.

An informatic database records the clinical and molecular data, diagnosis, muscle biopsy code number and location of each sample.

 The "Neuromuscular  Bank of Tissues and DNA samples" is supported by Telethon Italian Foundation since 1996.

The RD-Connect catalogue will allow for our samples to be more accessible to the wider scientific community and therefore help to establish new collaborations and enhance our networking activities in the field of RD research.

allData.name: Newcastle MRC Biobank for Rare and Neuromuscular Diseases

bb_core.Description: The MRC Biobank is a unique resource of human biomaterials aimed at supporting research of neuromuscular diseases by providing a continuous availability of high quality human specimens to the scientific community. The Biobank has over 8000 patient samples stored including muscle and skin cell lines, DNA, RNA, urine, serum and plasma with an aim of supporting various research activities such as study of the pathophysiology of neuromuscular  disorders, natural history studies, testing of novel therapeutic applications and biomarker studies. The MRC Biobank has been established and operating since 2008 at two sites, London and Newcastle to facilitate the current efforts in translational research.

address.name of host institution: Parkinson Institute, ASST "pini-CTO (ex Istituti Clinici di Perfezionamento

allData.name: Parkinson Institute Biobank

bb_core.Description:
Parkinson Institute Biobank

The main aim of the Parkinson Institute's Biobank, directed by dr. Roberto Cilia, is to collect and store DNA samples, as well as RNA, serum, cell lines and skin biopsies for histologic analysis, from patients affected by Parkinsonism and related movement disorders attending the Institute (http://www.parkinsonbiobank.com/).

The Parkinson Institute located in the Hospital – ASST “Pini-CTO” (formerly Istituti Clinici di Perfezionamento- ICP) in Milan, Italy directed by Professor Gianni Pezzoli is a specialized referral centre that operates in the field of movement disorders and that represents the ideal place where to start a DNA Bank for PD, allowing the collection of many samples from patients assessed and followed up according to homogeneous and highly specialized standards. All patients are fully characterized in terms of medical history, clinical findings, and any other relevant information and undergo detailed follow-up by a highly specialised team who resort to the most advanced diagnostic techniques and therapeutic measures available. All clinical and personal data are collected in full electronic medical records and in specific databases available to researchers. In addition to patients, controls not affected by neurodegenerative disease are also collected, usually among partners/caregivers (1500 entries). This enables us to collect a large group of healthy controls matched by ethnic and regional origin and by age. Since 2003, the Biobank is a member of the Telethon Genetic Biobank Network (TNGB, http://biobanknetwork.telethon.it/) and is revised by an international scientific committee yearly.
bb_core.Additional_Biomaterial_prepared: DNA, RNA, Serum, Fibroblast cell lines, Skin biopsies for histologic analysis.
